title: 111_hr5514
content: The Act is titled the "National Activity Based Total Accountability Act of 2010" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that the Federal Government sends billions of dollars to States annually for various purposes such as health care, transportation, housing, education, and agriculture. States receive this funding through various means like grants, loans, and direct appropriations. Some States are more effective than others in utilizing these taxpayer dollars. The purpose of this Act is to improve government accountability at the State level by promoting objective data sharing and competition among States to demonstrate efficiency in spending taxpayer dollars. The Act aims to enhance government accountability at the State level by mandating annual accountings using total accountability measures, including unit-cost data. The Act mandates State governments receiving Federal financial assistance to submit annual fiscal accounting reports to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These reports must include a one-page summary of total funding and expenditures for each budget entity, along with unit-cost summaries for each entity. The Director is required to publish these reports on an Internet website within 30 days of receiving them. SEC. 4. STANDARDIZATION OF STATE FISCAL ACCOUNTING REPORTS. The Director will standardize State fiscal accounting reports for comparison purposes. States must submit program descriptions to the Director within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Data will be classified based on submitted descriptions and relevant data sources. The Director will establish a uniform system for classifying agency activities, identify conduct for each activity unit, and define performance measures for each agency activity. The Director will establish a uniform system for classifying agency activities and defining performance measures. The unit-cost summary for a budget entity of a State government must be one page long and include funds available, agency activities, and a reconciliation of funds with expenditures. SEC. 6. STATEMENT OF FUNDS AVAILABLE. A statement of funds available shall identify each source of funds for expenditure by the budget entity and the sum of all amounts. Sources include State appropriations, Federal financial assistance, and other sources as determined by the Director. SEC. 7. AGENCY ACTIVITY LINE ITEM LISTINGS. The agency activity line item listing must identify the activity, total funds expended, activity units, and unit cost. It should also describe conduct, purposes, and intended beneficiaries of the activity. The agency activity line item listing must identify the activity, total funds expended, activity units, and unit cost, as well as describe conduct, purposes, and intended beneficiaries. Expenditures for agency activities without a method of measurement must be allocated to similar activities with measurable outcomes. Total funds expended should include payments to contractors or subordinate entities. Unit-cost of agency activities must be determined. The unit-cost of an agency activity is determined using a specific formula. The formula for determining the unit-cost of an agency activity involves UC, m, and q as defined terms. Additionally, there is a provision for reconciling funds available with adjusted expenditures. SEC. 8. RECONCILIATION OF FUNDS AVAILABLE WITH ADJUSTED EXPENDITURES. This section outlines the process for reconciling adjusted expenditures of a budget entity with funds available for expenditure or obligation. Adjusted expenditures are determined by the formula AE = EXP + PT + REV. SEC. 9. NONCOMPLIANCE. A budget entity can identify pass-throughs and reversions based on criteria set by the Director. If a State government fails to file a timely fiscal accounting report, the Director will notify Federal departments to withhold 10% of financial assistance for the next year. The Director can create necessary rules, and definitions are provided in the Act. SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. The term "State government" refers to the government of each State, the District of Columbia, and any U.S. commonwealth, territory, or possession. "Budget entity" means a State agency or the State judiciary. "Agency activity" refers to major operational activities of a budget entity. "Federal financial assistance" includes amounts determined appropriate by the Director.
